item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: The journal eLife, which made the apparently brilliant decision to publish *before* peer review, actually "desk rejects" a whopping 73% of papers (including two of mine, erm, but never mind). So the gate-keeping is not gone but rather it has moved from the reviewers to... the editors. I think it was a mistake, especially for the journal who did so much to improve the review process by having reviewers consult each other. For more opinions, see this thread by Bevil Conway: https://twitter.com/BevilConway/status/1667877280880705536

item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description: @MatteoCarandini Conway is misrepresenting the data. The rate of desk reject is the same as before. If anything can be concluded is that unfortunately the rate hasn‚Äôt changed, as in, perhaps it would be good to accept more.The fear some senior editors had upon the introduction of the new publication model was that precisely desk reject would go up for fear of ‚Äúpre-accepting‚Äù papers that upon peer review may turn out to be flawed. This has not materialised. So on this dimension the new model is a success. In every other dimension it‚Äôs the same as the old model, except authors now have more power. I am calling this a good outcome.Disclosure: I‚Äôm a senior editor at eLife.

item.title: Hilda Bastian
item.description: 17 studies plus advertising data map out Twitter's decline. My latest post @PLOS https://absolutelymaybe.plos.org/2023/06/07/17-studies-plus-advertising-data-map-out-twitters-decline/I tackled 5 questions that look at decline in quality & quantity from various angles. The answer to all of them was worse than I'd expected.As much as a third of Twitter users have either left, or are tweeting less...But the far right, hate, & misinfo are booming. Promoted tweets are shifting in worrying directions, too.

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description:
Our lab at UCL (https://www.ucl.ac.uk/cortexlab) is looking for a Research Technician. It is an exciting opportunity to practice research in computational and experimental #neuroscience. Ideal for those who wish to have strong research experience before considering PhD studies.The job involves training mice to perform a task and recording their brain activity with techniques such as 2-photon imaging and Neuropixels recordings.To learn more and apply: https://www.ucl.ac.uk/cortexlab/positions
Deadline: 20 June.
